item.title: Algebraic Closure
item.description: Definition (Algebraic Closure). Let $K$ be a field extension of $F$. The set $$ \lbrace \alpha \in K \mid \alpha \text{ is algebraic over }F \rbrace $$is called the algebraic closure of $F$ in $K$.

item.title: Criteria for Algebraic Extensions
item.description: Proposition 1. Let $K$ be a field extension of $F$. If each $\alpha_i \in K$ is algebraic over $F$, then $F[\alpha_1, \ldots , \alpha_n]$ is a finite dimensional field extension of $F$ with $$ [F[\alpha_1, \ldots , \alpha_n] : F] \leq \prod_{i=1}^n [F(\alpha_i): F].

item.title: Transitivity of Algebraic Field Extensions
item.description: This note proves two transitive properties of field extensions, the first is of the degree of fields, and the second is about algebraic field extensions.

item.title: Affine Coordinate Ring
item.description: We can view elements of $k[x_1, \ldots , x_n]$ as functions on $\mathbb A^n$ by evaluating them at points of $k^n$.

item.title: Affine Variety
item.description: Definition (Affine Variety). An affine algebraic variety, or an affine variety, is an irreducible algebraic set in $\mathbb A^n$. An open set of an affine variety is called a quasi-affine variety.

item.title: Algebraic Field Extensions
item.description: Definition (Algebraic Element, Transcendental Element). If $K$ is a field extension of $F$, then an element $\alpha \in K$ is algebraic over $F$ if there is a nonzero polynomial $f(x) \in F[x]$ with $f(\alpha) = 0$.

item.title: Basic Definitions for Fields
item.description: We collect here some basic definitions and examples of field extensions. Recall that a field is a commutative ring with identity such that the nonzero elements form a group under multiplication.

item.title: Generators of Fields
item.description: Definition (Finitely Generated Extension). Let $K$ be a field extension of $F$. if $X$ is a subset of $K$, then the ring $F[X]$ generated by $F$ and $X$ is the intersection of all subrings of $K$ that contain $F$ and $X$.

item.title: Minimal Polynomials
item.description: The minimal polynomial is an extremely useful tool to determine the degree of a field extension as well as other properties.

item.title: Prime Ideals and Irreducible Sets
item.description: Here we find another theorem that lets us pass back and forth between algebra and geometry. Theorem. An algebraic set is irreducible if and only if its vanishing ideal is a prime ideal.

item.title: Eisenstein's Criterion

item.title: Irreducible Spaces
item.description: Definition (Irreducible Space). A nonempty subset $Y$ of a topological space $X$ is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union $Y = Y_1 \cup Y_2$ of two proper subsets, each one of which is closed in $Y$.

item.title: Hilbert Basis Theorem
item.description: In this note we prove that a polynomial ring over a Noetherian ring is Noetherian. The idea of the proof is to take an ideal $I$ of $R[x]$ and create an ideal in $R$ that consists of all the leading coefficients of polynomials in $I$.
